name: zipeprol
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1366

name: zipeprol
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1366
Reason: To predict the melting point of Zipeprol, we evaluate its functional groups and structure compared to a reference substance. A common reference for aromatic compounds is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. Zipeprol is a more complex molecule with several functional groups that influence its melting point: two phenyl groups, two oxygen atoms in ether linkages, a tertiary amine, and an alcohol group. Each phenyl group (aromatic rings) adds rigidity and increases the melting point by about +30°C. Ether linkages have a slight increase in dispersion forces, estimated as +5°C each. The tertiary amine is less straightforward; tertiary amines don't strongly affect the melting point, so its effect might be negligible. Lastly, the alcohol group can form hydrogen bonds, which significantly increases the melting point by about +40°C. Combining these effects, we anticipate shifts from the reference point as follows: +60°C (phenyl groups) + 10°C (ether linkages) + 0°C (tertiary amine) + 40°C (alcohol group).

name: zipeprol
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1366
Reason: To predict the melting point of zipeprol, we should consider the influence of its functional groups relative to a simple reference molecule. For aromatic compounds, benzene with a melting point of 5.5°C is a common starting point. Zipeprol contains several functional groups that will affect its melting point: two phenyl groups, two ether linkages (each involving one oxygen atom), a tertiary amine, and an alcohol group. Typically, phenyl groups increase the melting point due to enhanced pi-pi interactions and increased molecular rigidity; we approximate this increase at about +15°C for each phenyl group. The ether oxygen atoms contribute to the polarity and can engage in dipole-dipole interactions, potentially raising the melting point by about +5°C for each ether linkage. The tertiary amine has a negligible effect on the melting point due to the lack of significant hydrogen bonding capability, so we assign it 0°C. The alcohol group, however, can form intermolecular hydrogen bonds, which are strong and significantly increase the melting point; we estimate this increase to be about +40°C. Summing these contributions, we make the following predictions: +30°C for two phenyl groups, +10°C for two ether linkages, +40°C for the alcohol group, with no additional melting point increase from the tertiary amine.
